abstract: The city’s leader promised to withdraw unpopular legislation that ignited protests in June, but demonstrators’ demands have expanded since then.

abstract: After a summer of demonstrating in the streets to demand greater rights, students brought their activism to school.

abstract: The exit of John Slosar would be the second high-profile departure from the carrier, which has been rocked by protests in its home city, since last month.

abstract: The popular horse races — which draw a mix of Cantonese bettors and beer-swilling expats — had until now been largely unhurt by the unrest roiling the city.

abstract: The ruling follows a yearlong judicial battle between the caretaker Socialist government and the dictator’s family.

abstract: Vice Chair Richard Clarida signaled another cut could be coming but stopped short of promising one, saying the Fed is taking decisions one by one.

abstract: The Belgian Air Force jet went down over western France, causing both pilots onboard to use their ejector seats and parachutes. Both escaped with minor injuries.

abstract: A.I. research is becoming increasingly expensive, leaving few people with easy access to the computing firepower necessary to develop the technology.

abstract: The pope unveiled the sculpture in St. Peter’s Square during a special Mass and portrayed migration as an opportunity to “promote the integral human development of all people.”

abstract: The strike by the United Auto Workers, in its fifth day, is causing layoffs in related operations but has not yet resulted in shortages at dealers.

abstract: American counterterrorism officials are voicing alarm about a Qaeda affiliate in Syria that they say is plotting attacks from the country’s northwest.

abstract: The new deployment is part of an expanding series of military and diplomatic steps the United States has taken to defuse tensions with Turkey, a NATO ally.

abstract: More than 2,000 people evacuated to Nassau from ravaged islands, almost all Haitian, are in shelters with nowhere to go. ‘Some dogs are living better.’

abstract: Robert A. Iger, Disney’s chief executive and chairman, had been on the board since 2011. But both companies will debut streaming services next month.

headline: Two Men in Japan Dared to Take Paternity Leave. It Cost Them Dearly, They Say.
abstract: The men bucked norms that parental leave is for women and say that, when they returned to work, their companies punished them with demotions and pay cuts.

headline: A Hard Lesson for Migrants Who Give Up: There May Be No Welcome Mat Back Home
abstract: An estimated one in four people who migrate in search of opportunity return to their country of birth, by choice or otherwise. For many, it’s a rocky transition.

headline: ​Job One for Saudis’ New Energy Chief: Picking Up the Pieces
abstract: Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman was named energy minister less than a week before an aerial attack crippled Saudi Arabia’s oil production.

headline: Why We Still Debate Election Debates
abstract: Compared to the United States’, televised leaders’ debates came late to Canada, and we’re still figuring them out.

abstract: Restaurant owners say Grubhub’s business model has cut into their profit margins. A New York City Council committee is investigating.

abstract: The company behind brands like a famous ketchup and Oscar Mayer meats is dealing with slumping sales, shareholder lawsuits, layoffs and questions about its accounting practices.

headline: How North Korea’s Leader Gets His Luxury Cars
abstract: Kim Jong-un parades around in Mercedes-Benzes and a Rolls-Royce, despite sanctions intended to keep North Korea from importing luxury goods. We tracked how they get there.

headline: Two Blows Are Dealt to Ukrainian Leader’s Clean-Government Image
abstract: In a setback for President Volodymyr Zelensky, international lenders criticized government corruption and left Kiev without a deal. A top aide also stepped down.

headline: In Hong Kong, Unity Between Peaceful and Radical Protesters. For Now.
abstract: Five years ago, protesters were critical of even breaking windows. Now, some are throwing firebombs.

headline: Kurz Wins Austria Election. Will He Turn to Far Right or Greens to Govern?
abstract: Sebastian Kurz, who came in first in a snap election in Austria, has a choice: Partner again with the far-right party that collapsed his government or shift left?

headline: Impeachment, Boris Johnson, Austria Elections: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know

headline: Why We Upgraded Our Reviews Approach for Apple’s iPhone 11
abstract: While tech reviewers last week encouraged people to upgrade to Apple’s newest phones, The New York Times recommended something different: to cherish the phone you have, and upgrade if you must. Here’s why.

headline: Indonesia’s Leader Faces Student Protests and Crises Heading Into New Term
abstract: President Joko Widodo’s decision to limit the power of Indonesia’s anticorruption commission has helped set off protests before his second term begins.

headline: Former Head of Danske Bank in Estonia Is Found Dead in Suicide
abstract: The death of Aivar Rehe, whose bank served as a hub for dirty money, is another twist in a scandal that expanded on Wednesday to include Deutsche Bank.

headline: How to Make the Most of Apple’s New Privacy Tools in iOS 13
abstract: We tested the new suite of privacy tools in Apple’s latest mobile software, from minimizing location sharing to silencing robocalls.

headline: In the Salary Race, Engineers Sprint but English Majors Endure
abstract: Technical skills taught in college have a short shelf life, while a liberal arts education prepares graduates for jobs that haven’t been invented yet.

headline: Tax Law’s Cap on State and Local Deductions Is Upheld by Court
abstract: A federal judge rejected a suit by four states, including New York, over a part of the 2017 tax overhaul that they said penalized Democratic states.

headline: Yang vs. Warren: Who Has the Better Tax Plan?
abstract: Andrew Yang’s proposed V.A.T. and $1,000 dividend would be more practical than Senator Warren’s wealth tax, in the view of the economist N. Gregory Mankiw.

headline: Syria Demands Immediate Withdrawal of U.S. and Turkish Forces, Again
abstract: Syria’s foreign minister demanded both countries evacuate their forces from the war-ravaged country or face “countermeasures.” Syria has made such threats before without taking steps to enforce them.

headline: Brother of Qandeel Baloch, Pakistani Internet Star, Gets Life Term for Her Murder
abstract: The case had returned the spotlight to a rampant practice of “honor killings” in Pakistan. The assailants often go free because the victim’s family forgives the killer.

headline: Austria’s Kurz, Leading in Polls, Looks Open to Reunion With Far Right
abstract: Four months after scandal imploded Sebastian Kurz’s coalition, the wunderkind conservative looks set to win again in Sunday’s election. Will he embrace the far right a second time?

headline: Haiti Gripped by Violent Protests Amid Calls for President’s Ouster
abstract: Streets, schools and banks were closed throughout the country, bringing the economy to a standstill. “President Jovenel Moise is not doing anything for us, just killing us,” said a protester.

headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows New on Netflix Canada in October
abstract: Every month, Netflix Canada adds a batch of movies and TV shows to its library. Here are the titles we think are most interesting for October.

headline: The Week in Tech: Why Californians Have Better Privacy Protections
abstract: While Congress has stalled on new privacy bills, a real estate developer is pushing for broader data rights in the Golden State.

headline: Turkey’s Radical Plan: Send a Million Refugees Back to Syria
abstract: Facing economic troubles in Turkey, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan is pushing a plan to resettle refugees in a United States-controlled swath of Syria.

headline: Brownface, Blackface and About-Face. Is Trudeau Who He Says He Is?
abstract: Many Canadians saw Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s record in office as evidence in his favor, if not enough to exonerate him for recent photos and video showing him wearing dark makeup.

headline: Syrian Children Saved a German Village. And a Village Saved Itself.
abstract: Four years after Germany took in over one million migrants, integration is quietly working, one village at a time.

headline: Israel’s Arab Politicians Emerge With New Political Heft
abstract: A higher voter turnout translated into power for Israel’s Arab alliance, opening up possibilities for a more influential role in the political arena.

headline: As Taiwan Loses Influence, China Gains Ground in Race With U.S.
abstract: Two Pacific nations severed ties with Taiwan in favor of Beijing this week, boosting China in its contest with the United States for influence in the region.

headline: U.K. Supreme Court Declared Boris Johnson’s Actions Unlawful. What Happens Next?
abstract: The ruling puts Parliament back in session almost three weeks earlier than expected, and has consequences for Brexit.

headline: What We Found About Notre-Dame’s Lead, and What It May Mean for You
abstract: Every expert consulted by The New York Times said it was still safe to visit Paris, though they differed on what precautions should be taken.

headline: Russian Man Pleads Guilty in ‘Massive’ Hacking Scheme
abstract: Andrei Tyurin is the first person to be convicted in the case, in which prosecutors said cyberattacks targeted a dozen American companies, including JPMorgan Chase.

headline: Hong Kong’s Leader, Carrie Lam, to Withdraw Extradition Bill That Ignited Protests
abstract: The move eliminates a major objection among protesters, but it was unclear if it would be enough to bring an end to intensifying demonstrations.

headline: Jeffrey Katzenberg’s Streaming Platform Loses a Top Executive
abstract: Janice Min, the former editor of The Hollywood Reporter and Us Weekly, has left Quibi months ahead of its planned launch.

headline: Pope Says It’s ‘an Honor That the Americans Attack Me’
abstract: En route to Mozambique at the start of a six-day trip, Pope Francis called it “an honor that the Americans attack me,” and seemed eager to read a new book about it.

headline: Norway’s Viking Ships Defied Time, but Tourism May Be a Fiercer Foe
abstract: The Norwegian government has earmarked $200 million to restore and move two Viking longships under threat from a surge in visitors to their museum.

headline: Radio Free Europe Is Poised to Return to a Less Free Hungary
abstract: The return of the Cold War-era service, which was used to combat authoritarianism, is likely to be taken as an affront by the Orban government and, perhaps, President Trump.

headline: Mexico Says It Has Cut the Number of Migrants Heading to U.S.
abstract: The government, which had faced economic pressure from the Trump administration, said the flow had been cut in half since spring.

headline: New Government Takes Shape in Italy, Sidelining Salvini and the Hard Right
abstract: The turnabout in Italy’s politics was as a relief to the European establishment. But the new coalition may prove no more stable, or less conflict-ridden, than the one it replaces.

headline: From the Shadows, China’s Communist Party Mobilizes Against Hong Kong Protests
abstract: In Hong Kong, the party is officially nonexistent, but it is in the vanguard of an increasingly firm pushback against the demonstrations.

headline: After Backlash, Boris Johnson Promises to Speed Up Brexit Talks With Brussels
abstract: The prime minister sought to calm fury over his maneuver to suspend Parliament and limit the ability of his critics to thwart a “no-deal” Brexit.

headline: Britain’s Queen Is a Figurehead, but She Just Got Dragged Into Brexit Politics
abstract: When Boris Johnson asked Queen Elizabeth II to suspend Parliament, many who opposed his move hoped she would intervene. But experts say she had little sway over the matter.

headline: Hamas Arrests 10 Suspects in Gaza Suicide Bombings
abstract: The suspects in suicide bombings that killed three police officers are said to be a part of Salafi jihadism, a movement that often clashes with Hamas.

headline: W.H.O. Warns of ‘Dramatic’ Rise in Measles in Europe
abstract: The disease had a resurgence in Britain, Greece, the Czech Republic and Albania, the World Health Organization said.

headline: Beijing’s Hong Kong Strategy: More Arrests, No Concessions
abstract: Officials say that many more demonstrators will face charges, and that none of their movement’s demands will be met.

headline: Twitter C.E.O. Jack Dorsey’s Account Hacked
abstract: Mr. Dorsey’s account began posting racial epithets, profanities and bomb threats on Friday afternoon. A company spokesman confirmed it was hacked.

headline: Hong Kong’s Chief Executive Is Disheartened, but No Successor Is in Sight
abstract: Carrie Lam acknowledged that the protests had left her in turmoil, but vowed not to resign. Those close to Beijing say it would not let her even if she wanted to.

headline: Victoria’s Secret Had Troubles, Even Before Jeffrey Epstein
abstract: L Brands, the brand’s parent company, plans to detail an overhaul next week as it struggles with changing tastes and an embarrassing connection to the Epstein scandal.

headline: New Google and Facebook Inquiries Show Big Tech Scrutiny Is Rare Bipartisan Act
abstract: Democrats and Republicans at both the federal and state levels are uniting to investigate the power of Big Tech and, potentially, to rein in the dominant companies.

headline: The Polaris RZR, an Off-Road Thrill That Can Go Up in Flames
abstract: The Polaris RZR, a vehicle for recreational use, has been linked to scores of fires and four deaths. But its maker insists it is safe.

headline: For Europe, the Threat of a No-Deal Brexit Comes at a Bad Time
abstract: With the German and Italian economies in trouble, a so-called “hard Brexit” could tip the entire continent toward a recession.

headline: When Apps Get Your Medical Data, Your Privacy May Go With It
abstract: Medical groups are warning that new federal data-sharing rules, enabling people to get their health records through a smartphone, could lead to invasions of privacy.

headline: Cooking Eggs in the Morning and Shucking Oysters at Night, Thanks to an App
abstract: Facing a labor shortage, restaurants are turning to on-demand services for line cooks, dishwashers and other trained workers.

headline: Abaco Islands, at a Remove From the Bahamas’ Resorts, Feel Dorian’s Wrath
abstract: The small islands, sparsely populated by fishermen, manual laborers and migrants from Haiti, reportedly had thousands of homes damaged or destroyed by Hurricane Dorian.

headline: Epstein’s Island, ‘Little St. Jeff’s’: A Hideaway Where Money Bought Influence
abstract: Jeffrey Epstein used his islands as a personal and corporate haven, negotiating lucrative local tax breaks even as he faced inquiries for sexual misconduct.

headline: Attack at School in China Leaves at Least 8 Children Dead
abstract: The police said they had arrested a 40-year-old male suspect, but the local authorities did not mention the method of attack or a possible motive.

headline: After Meeting With Trump, a Myanmar Clergyman Could Be Prosecuted
abstract: In the Oval Office, a prominent Baptist minister accused the Myanmar military of oppression and torture. A colonel later filed a complaint against him.

headline: A Greenhouse Large Enough to Feed the Eastern Seaboard
abstract: AppHarvest, the largest greenhouse in the United States, will begin shipping 45 million pounds of fresh produce annually to grocery stores when it opens next summer.

headline: North Korea Missile Tests, ‘Very Standard’ to Trump, Show Signs of Advancing Arsenal
abstract: American intelligence officials and outside experts say that Kim Jong-un is capitalizing on President Trump’s downplaying of his weapons testing to significantly improve the North’s arsenal.

headline: The Trump Secrets Hiding Inside Deutsche Bank
abstract: The president’s longtime lender has extensive documents related to Mr. Trump’s personal and business finances. Here’s what they could reveal.

headline: Tens of Thousands Take to Streets to Protest Boris Johnson Maneuver in Parliament
abstract: Protesters in London and dozens of other cities and towns spoke of worries for democracy over the decision to suspend Parliament for several potentially critical weeks before Brexit.

headline: In Bahamas, a Blind Father Wades to Safety, His Disabled Son on His Shoulders
abstract: Against all odds, Brent Lowe escaped the wrath of Hurricane Dorian. Now the real struggle begins.

headline: Hurricane Dorian Batters Bahamas, Killing at Least 5: ‘a Historic Tragedy’
abstract: Dorian may be super-powerful, but it’s moving at a snail’s pace. That gives its torrential rains more time to produce floods, and its winds more time to destroy.

headline: In a Tight Labor Market, a Disability May Not Be a Barrier
abstract: To expand the pool of workers, companies are recruiting stay-at-home parents, retirees and people with disabilities. Will they keep it up if the economy sours?

headline: How Many Humps on a Camel? In Kazakhstan, It’s Complicated
abstract: To diversify away from oil, Kazakhstan is supporting an ancient form of camel hybridization. Hump variations abound.

headline: A Million Refugees May Soon Lose Their Line to the Outside World
abstract: As Bangladesh vowed to cut off mobile phone access in Rohingya camps, refugees who fled terror in Myanmar despaired over their future.

headline: U.K. Democracy, Tested by Brexit and Boris Johnson, Holds for Now
abstract: Deep into an era of tear-it-all-down populism, democratic safeguards are, for once, working as intended.

headline: In Zimbabwe, the Water Taps Run Dry and Worsen ‘a Nightmare’
abstract: Most residents in the country’s capital only get running water once a week, leading to serpentine queues at municipal boreholes across the city.

headline: As Grass-Roots Labor Activism Rises, Will Unions Take Advantage?
abstract: Worker organizing is often being done with little union involvement or help. “It’s an opportunity being squandered,” one former labor official said.

headline: Google Is Fined $170 Million for Violating Children’s Privacy on YouTube
abstract: As part of a settlement, YouTube said it would also institute new privacy measures on children’s videos. Critics said the changes did not go far enough to protect children.

headline: The World’s First Ambassador to the Tech Industry
abstract: Denmark appointed him to approach Silicon Valley as if it were a global superpower. His challenges show how smaller countries struggle to influence giant corporations.

headline: Walmart’s C.E.O. Steps Into the Gun Debate. Other C.E.O.s Should Follow.
abstract: Doug McMillon, Walmart’s chief executive, said the company would stop selling certain types of guns and ammunition. This should be an example for corporate America.

headline: Police Use of Facial Recognition Is Accepted by British Court
abstract: In a closely watched case, a judge ruled that live facial recognition does not violate privacy rights. There has been little legal precedent about its use.

headline: Who Got the E.U.’s Top Jobs
abstract: A German supporter of a “United States of Europe,” a French power broker, a Belgian coalition-builder and a Spanish socialist will try to lead the European Union through complex times.

headline: Greece Liked to Underestimate Kyriakos Mitsotakis. Now He’s Prime Minister.
abstract: After sweeping to victory in a general election on Sunday, it seems the leader of the center-right New Democracy party may have the last laugh.

headline: E.U. Ministers, Scrambling to Save Iran Nuclear Deal, Play Down Breaches
abstract: “There is no alternative” to the 2015 deal that President Trump has rejected and Iran is backing away from, the European Union’s foreign policy chief said.

headline: A Brexit Protest, Reporters With Questions, but No Boris Johnson
abstract: A canceled news conference and a joke about the Hulk overshadowed critical meetings with European Union officials.

headline: Forever 21 Bankruptcy Signals a Shift in Consumer Tastes
abstract: The retailer fell victim to the eroding power of shopping malls and said it would cease operations in 40 countries and close up to 178 stores in the U.S.

headline: Bit by Bit, Socially Conscious Investors Are Influencing 401(k)’s
abstract: So-called E.S.G. funds still make up a small fraction of these workplace retirement plans, but they are gaining ground.

headline: For Afghans Scarred by War, ‘Peace Can’t Bring My Love Back’
abstract: We reached some of the victims of the conflict whose stories we have reported over the years to hear their views on a stalled peace deal.

headline: Looming Presence in Drug Conspiracy Case: Honduras’s President
abstract: President Juan Orlando Hernández, who won’t be at his brother’s U.S. trial, has been accused of using trafficking to “help assert power and control in Honduras.”

headline: In Israel, Gantz and Netanyahu Start Talks on Possible Unity Government
abstract: After Israel’s deadlock election, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his chief opponent, Benny Gantz, agreed to try to negotiate a power-sharing deal.

headline: A Man or a ‘Yellow Object’? Hong Kong Police Dispute Assault Allegations
abstract: A video is widely interpreted as capturing officers kicking a man in a yellow shirt. But the police say it was merely a “yellow object.”

headline: ‘Right to Be Forgotten’ Privacy Rule Is Limited by Europe’s Top Court
abstract: The European Court of Justice said the landmark privacy law cannot be enforced beyond the European Union.

headline: Trump-Rouhani Meeting Was a Near Miss, but Iran Leaves the Door Open
abstract: President Hassan Rouhani did not dismiss the idea that a meeting with the American leader was entirely possible — under conditions set by the Iranians.

headline: Afghanistan Presidential Vote Presses On Despite Concerns About Legitimacy
abstract: Accusations of systemic fraud and fears of Taliban threats have compromised an election that is likely to have the fewest voters since the first presidential vote in 2004.

headline: Greenland Calls On Denmark to Help Fight Child Sexual Abuse
abstract: A former mayor of the community of Tasiilaq said, “I believe we are in a human, social and cultural death spiral if we don’t manage to stop the sexual abuse.”

headline: Locast, a Free Streaming Service, Sues ABC, CBS, NBC and Fox
abstract: The nonprofit behind the app, which relays broadcast feeds online, claims the networks have colluded in an effort to shut it down.

headline: U.S. Military Again Strikes ISIS in Southern Libya
abstract: The Pentagon carried out its third airstrike in a week against ISIS fighters in Libya amid signs the group was seeking to increase its recruiting.

headline: Ninja, a Fortnite Star, Leaps From Twitch to Mixer
abstract: Tyler Blevins, 28, the multimillionaire gamer known as Ninja, says he has a deal to stream exclusively at the Microsoft service. He’s quitting Twitch, the Amazon service where he has over 14 million followers. Yes, it’s a big deal.

headline: A Giant Factory Rises to Make a Product Filling Up the World: Plastic
abstract: Royal Dutch Shell’s plant will produce more than a million tons of plastic, in the form of tiny pellets. Many in the Pittsburgh area see it as an economic engine, but others worry about long-term harm.
